ref.mixed-citation: Hesse is reluctant to ascribe pure formality even to quantum mechanics, opposing the Copenhagen view: though its adherents "refrain from making interpretations when talking about quantum theory, they [do not] also avoid implicit interpretations when actually using it in the process of research" (1966,48).

Fermi-Dirac statis- tics, rather than the conventional statistics of objects having self-identity, is due to such an interpretation; it can only be understood on account of the preference of the 'financial- balance' model of electrons' behavior upon that of the billiard balls: "The crucial step from formalism to interpretation in the argument occurs when what the observer cannot do— namely, make a certain distinction—is taken as to be a property of the system, namely, that there is no such distinction" (50-51).
